H0.text: Microtubule organization of spindle fibers is interfered with by colchicine at concentrations of 0.1‑1 µg/ml, causing mitotic arrest of dividing cells at metaphase by disrupting the spindle apparatus.

H1.text: DNA synthesis of spindle protein is interfered with by colchicine at concentrations of 0.1‑1 µg/ml, causing mitotic arrest of dividing cells at metaphase through disruption of the spindle apparatus.

H2.text: Membrane transport of spindle fibers is the cell function during division that colchicine interferes with at concentrations of 0.1–1 µg/ml, causing mitotic arrest of dividing cells at metaphase by disrupting the spindle apparatus.

H3.text: RNA synthesis of spindle protein is the cell function that colchicine, a natural plant product at concentrations of 0.1–1 µg/ml, interferes with during cell division, causing mitotic arrest of dividing cells at metaphase by disrupting the spindle apparatus.

A4.text: Inhibits microtubule polymerization by binding to its constitutive protein, tubulin.

A5.text: colchicine alters cellular division by inhibiting chromosome segregation during mitosis
